channel.title: [BATCH] Copying a file and putting it somewhere else
channel.description:
Okay how can i copy a file and then paste it in a file of my choice?
Thanks
MVP

item.title: [BATCH] Copying a file and putting it somewhere else
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:9, topic:190479”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=253947.msg2132324#msg2132324 date=1206380316]

honestly sounds like you need to throw away computer. BATCH SUCKS. IMO there should be a rule against posting batch shit.

People use batch files to do simple things for them, they done need a big fancy java program to move a file.

mvp, look in my sig before you ask other questions about batch, or just pm me.

Other than the fact Java is better because of one major reason, multi platform.
[/quote]
So? You could make the same thing in a Linux sh script by changing copy to cp.[/quote]

Then you could say .sh’s suck because it’s not multi platform.

Read full topic

item.title: [BATCH] Copying a file and putting it somewhere else
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

A good one is xcopy, as TeleNubby:

 xcopy %windir%\blah\blah.txt %windir%

This could copy ‘blah.txt’ from my blah folder in your windows directory(normally C:\WINDOWS) and put it on your windows directory (normally C:\WINDOWS)

C:\Documents and Settings\User>xcopy %windir%\blah\blah.txt %windir% C:\WINDOWS\blah\blah.txt 1 File(s) copied

thats what would happen if a folder called blah and blah.txt was in it in your windows folder.

Read full topic

item.title: [BATCH] Copying a file and putting it somewhere else
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

lol frank_.

You can use the ‘copy’ command, or the ‘xcopy’ command for more options. Google it.
And to one of the earliest posts, the ‘move’ command moves the file, not copies it.

Read full topic
